review_title: More a mediocre private company than a university
pros: Faculty are very friendly and accessible. There is a collegial environment and faculty work very hard to create a strong learning environment and do what they can with limited resources in spite of upper management.
cons: Northeastern is closer to being a middling tech company than a university, and it moves further away from being a university with each passing year. The president and provost do not see the original mission of universities (in-depth research, advancing knowledge, disciplinary expertise, etc) as valuable. In fact, they denigrate it.  The senior administration tries to get faculty to funnel their research into niche tech areas (almost completely sidelining the liberal arts) because these areas bring in quick money and have short-run, superficial "impact" (really, it seems to be mainly about flashy visibility in the news). They keep buying new campuses and buying people from other institutions instead of fully supporting existing faculty and enriching the learning experience in Boston.  To pay for all the new campuses they have increased the number of students paying tuition to the point where all of the students who apply to go to Northeastern in Boston cannot actually all be in Boston during the course of their undergrad careers.  First, they doubled up students in the dorms, and now a significant number of students will be forced to be at another "campus" location during part of their degrees (branded as "mobility").  The business people at the top bill Northeastern as a cutting-edge global university, but the buildings are shabby and tech infrastructure in classrooms is pitiful and frequently broken. The campuses outside of Boston, Oakland, and London are not real learning spaces and don't have regular faculty.

pros: The pay is decent as an EA.
cons: The Burlington, MA leadership team is very inhumane. They yell at their employees, are overbearing, and extremely micromanagy. No one is trusted to do anything on their own. There were standing leadership meetings scheduled every Friday at 1pm, and all attendees were expected to work through the weekend following the meeting. Meetings are scheduled over your lunch, and you are encouraged not to go out of the office for lunch. I've had the worst onboarding experience of my life, where months of old work were piled up for me to find on day 1 of my employment. I wasn't allowed the time to properly do any mandatory trainings, and it took almost a month to get access to software that I needed to do my job because my boss was unbelievably negligent. The practice and overall style of management in that office is extremely outdated, including their software and technology. Leadership is old, and only interested in doing things one way, and one way only. There is zero creativity. Leadership talks down to you, and you work for them, not with them. They lied about the hybrid expectation during the interview, stating it was flexible 1-2 in office, then pulled a hook line and sinker requiring me to be in office everyday. I wasn't allowed to have focus time on my calendar, I was told by my boss that I needed to be available at all times. My boss was very inconsiderate of people's time, she would drop sudden teams calls constantly checking in anytime I was granted a work from home day, after begging. Leadership had a very negative outlook on all things. The icing on the cake, no vending machines anywhere in this newish building.

pros: -- It's an impressive campus, and I'm sure actual employees do not have the experience I did.
cons: -- I was hired through an agency who told me I would be working full-time. During my interview, both people told me this was a new position that they were looking to hire someone for permanently, so it was not meant to be a temporary gig. -- On my first day, I was told that I'd be working 25 hours tops, and that my hours would likely vary due to how much work I had at the time. Most days, I was encouraged to leave early, but I wanted to learn more, so I stayed and did LinkedIn Learning, which I was told was a viable option for downtime. -- I also asked for more work, and was given the opportunity to create an interdepartmental document. However, I was given minimal information and no one returned my emails asking for help. -- I was also told I'd be working on a DEIA initiative, but was never invited to any of the meetings that took place about it. -- I was told I was being let go after three weeks, or eight days of employment. My superiors at the University said it was due to a lack of funding and that there wasn't enough work for me to justify creating a new position--but I had done nothing wrong. The staffing agency told me there was an issue with something I'd said on social media and "to scrub everything" about the University from social, which I did. I still don't know who was correct, but I do know it was a terrible experience and I missed out on a much better job because I wasted a few weeks at Northeastern.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, benefits, but that's it.
cons:
Culture is horrid. Faculty members across the board disrespect staff members left and right, acting like because they have a phd we all need to kiss the ground they walk on. In my year working here, I never once felt appreciated or supported by my department. My position really should have been two separate positions. 
Pay is abysmal, not competitive at all. I am an alumni of NU, but I am still living paycheck to paycheck as a working professional due to poor compensation and the immense amount of student loans I had to take out (even with scholarships). 

Upper management does not communicate and sends mixed messages down the chain, resulting in more work and more stress. 

Favoritism is rampant. Within my college, research staff were supposed to be on campus full-time, but was not extended to any position but mine. My colleagues all had a hybrid schedule and despite asking for this many times, I was denied. Instead, I had to jump through hoops with HR and DRC to get ADA accommodations.

This job exacerbated my mental health to the point I was required to take a medical leave of absence and enroll in a mental health program. Wasn't even able to utilize tuition reimbursement as my job left me entirely too exhausted to think about taking on classes in addition to my workload.

review_title: Great people, very poor pay, paternalistic culture, bad-tempered leadership
pros:
AMAZING colleagues, everywhere. There is genuine care for students and each other. Most Deans and Dean teams are good and caring. Several Chairs are tenured and a bit old school, but good people (I work at one College but have ties to 5 of the other 8 Colleges). 

Benefits OK. Not great, but OK.
cons:
Really, really bad pay. Everywhere. (Probably not at the Sr Vice Provost and above, though). 

An Associate Director role was just posted internally for the mid-70s, and that’s a full-time role and (knowing NU) over 40 hours. People at NU who’ve worked here a long time don’t even realize how “off” that is for an Associate Director role in Boston’s higher ed. 

Professors with 25-30 years’ experience in industry come on board when semi-retired because their average pay is $100k. It’s awful. Associate Dean’s? Not much more. (and all non-tenured, which pays low… but tenured isn’t too much higher)

I realize it’s a non-profit, but then we see them spend millions on old-school physical footprints… (as the Boston campus breaks down and classrooms are broken). 

It’s not that NU doesn’t have the money. It’s where they decide to spend it. 

If you’re looking at higher ed, I sadly recommend BU or any of the others vs NU if pay matters.

Culture is a known paternalistic one. The longer President Aoun stays on top, the more out of touch NU leaders become. Known for his temper (yells and demeans others, expects reverence), no one can say no or have an open discussion about how to improve the University. You might think you’ve had an active-listening, supportive exchange only to find out your Dean’s now on the block. Maybe I’ve been sheltered the last 30 years, but I’ve never seen a leader behave like him and remain on payroll. What you see is not who he is, and decisions are made based on how he’ll respond not whether its best for NU.

review_title: If you care about equity, don’t work here
pros:
A lot of opportunities for learning and development. Good technology & access to resources.
Fairly good guest speakers.
cons:
I’ve seen countless cases of nepotism, cronyism, and favoritism related to hiring, promotion, and raises. When I’ve seen this, information on what makes this person the best person for the job is rarely shared. There also seems to be a lack of transparency related to recruitment, hiring processes & practices, and not enough community involvement. 

I’ve seen a lot of great emails and speakers related to Black Lives Matter, but very slow changes and minimal opportunities for community involvement. We need new people to bring in new ideas and not just focus on reforming systems & practices that have failed people of color.

review_title: Get your benefits and get out
pros: there are great benefits (free tuition for employee and spouse/dependents, a 10% 403b match from NU, good vacation time, lots of paid holidays - like the whole week from Christmas Eve until New Year's Day), good location in the city right at a commuter rail stop as well as the Orange and Green lines of the MBTA system
cons: There's no job training, so good looking trying to figure anything out! As for getting stuff done with other offices, try and find good workers and butter them up so they'll help you, because good help is hard to find. You will come across plenty of un-motivated employees who only work until their kids graduate on free tuition from the university. The staff also dictate to management how work is split up, in that some staff just flat-out refuse to do tasks within their job description, so either the jobs don't get done, or are piled by management on staff members who have a work ethic. I was shocked when I saw a clerical staff tell her manager, "No, I'm not doing it. I already did a report this morning" when asked to do an urgent report in the afternoon. She was also shopping online when she said this. Not only was the work then given to someone else, but the employee was not even spoken to about this attitude.

pros:
• Overall, I really think that the university is a great place to work, and the school has a unique vision and opportunity in higher education. 

• Autonomy in the classroom (also could be a con for students), meaning you could teach and evaluate in a manner that you thought best for your subject and classroom. 

• Ample opportunity to get involved in many initiatives, or create new initiative for students—in my case this increased responsibility meant increased salary. (See below for con on this point).
cons:
• Lack of training and organization—especially for adjunct faculty. Unless you had pre-existing relationships with existing faculty I could see it being incredibly hard to understand your responsibilities and how your courses fit into the overall curriculum.

• Despite being encouraged to help students with extra-curricular activities, there were massive managerial failures at the senior leadership level surrounding the program, expectations, compensation, etc. Often it was a game of "he-said, she-said" that was frustrating for me—but more importantly, for students. It looks like this inefficiency has been improved since, but I think it's a big problem for the college. 

• My advice for other adjuncts in particular: ask lots of questions, get involved in the community, and document everything in writing. If you go above and beyond, I truly believe the school will reward you for it, but you need to watch out for yourself because of the lack of organization and shuffle of responsibility. Make sure you're speaking to a decision maker and have documentation of expectations, and you'll be set.

review_title: Great benefits including education, low entry salary, high turnover, lots of red tape
pros: Northeastern is a great place to work mainly because of the benefits. In addition to having your tuition waived as an employee, education is also free for your spouse and children, upon acceptance to the University. The costs of health, dental and vision insurance are very affordable. Employees are also given every major holiday off, flex hours during the summer (as determined by their department), a paid week off between Christmas and New Years in addition to their accrued vacation, sick and personal time. Overall, this is a great place to work if you need more work-life balance and if you are starting or caring for a family. It's also great for recent graduates to continue their education while getting real world experience after graduation.
cons: From my experience working on the administrative side of the University, there is a lot of red tape here, for no reason. Colleges and offices compete with one another, rather than working together toward a common goal. The salary paid is low, and for staff or low professional grade levels, they are not willing to negotiate. Even when superiors have requested raises for the department, they are rarely, if ever, given. Unlike the corporate world, high risk does not equal high reward. The interoffice politics are suffocating at times, but a reality of working here.

However Advancement does not because we are apparently so committed to the capital campaign. The school advertises great health insurance, workout facilities,etc. as part of the recruiting process. However, the copays are high, the insurance won't pay for a lot of high end procedures and tests, and there is an almost market rate membership fee for for the gyms (which are very crowded with students). The library is solid and free to use. :) The Adv. Off. is a highly politicized pressure cooker. They churn staff at a brisk pace. review_title: Great staff and students, poor presidential leadership.
pros: great benefits, including a generous retirement contribution. Generous vacation time for professional staff. Some very hard-working staff who care about the university and its students, some of the best coworkers I have ever had.  My direct supervisor is immensely supportive of the staff in my office, and shows respect and appreciation for the work they do. The students are very motivated and ambitious, partly due to the coop program and the experience they gain. They have high expectations, keeping you on your toes to work with them. There are plenty of opportunities to be creative in order to meet their needs.
cons: President Aoun is a petty little man, who seems to think he's morally and intrinsically superior to everyone else, just because he's the president of a university. He's an autocrat who shows no respect for the people who work for him. Professional staff are treated like second-class citizens, and faculty are treated only somewhat better. There have also been instances where he has been shut down to students, the prime constituents of our university. He lashes out at any one who offers constructive criticism. He has started chipping away at some staff benefits, such as the 4 day work week in the summer.

job_title: Assistant Coop Education Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Northeastern’s benefits are amazing—great health/dental, great vacation time and sick time, and if you don’t have a higher degree, the free master’s degree opportunity is amazing. Overall a great place to work—depending which college you get into within the university.
cons: An Asst. Co-op Coordinator is essentially a salesman. You are going out into the field trying to develop new jobs and employer partnerships. At the end of the day, if you don’t have 100% student placement, you are not doing your job. Teaching and advising students is very minimal to what you are expected to do: develop jobs. If you are not bringing new jobs and accounts in, it is negative, which can prevent you from a raise and/or promotion. It can be very stressful and anxiety inducing. If a co-op coordinator can last longer than 2-3 years, that is an accomplishment.

pros: Great Benefits, Great coworkers, easy to get to
cons: Awful leadership, treated like robots, staff in and out like a revolving door b/c it's so awful to work there

pros: Great benefits. I had the opportunity to complete a Master's Degree due to my tuition reimbursement benefits. Other benefits are great as well, such as a discount on car insurance, health insurance, etc. As a strong academic institution, there are many opportunities to further yourself in addition to classes through lectures, seminars and guest speakers. Employees are motivated to assist students and their overall dedication for the students well-being can be inspiring.
cons: New employees to the university enter highly motivated to assist students. Weathered employees tend to count the days until their retirement. The University has dramatically changed over the past 10 years (physically and ideologically). Many weathered employees (those who have worked for 3+ years) tend to resist change and fight new ideas. Movement up the ladder is not easy. Often you need to get the attention of senior management to be considered for a higher position, whether you are qualified or not. Although administrators try to assist students in their needs, administrators tend to give the "NU Shuffle" to other employees sending them on a goose chase to find the answers. Overall, it is a very administrative bureaucracy.

review_title: Student Services Specialist, International Student & Scholar Institute
job_title: Student Services Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Great work environment - A chance to learn more that you will will need to know about international student & scholar regulations - Over 10,500 international students long make Northeastern the university with the 4th largest population of international students - Great co-op program and almost over a 60 to 70% of students applying for OPT (work authorization) makes this office the best place to learn about CPT and OPT - great place to interact with internationals and learn about their culture and customs, office organizes so many cultural events and student programs including a 2 month long international student event called Carnevale - so much free food all round the year
cons: Too much work stress on advisors is what I observed - its busy out there! All around the year, its always crazy at the front desk - Not a very green office (staff does not necessarily recycle paper or plastic on a personal level)

pros: 22 sick days and 15 vacation days in the first year of employment plus 13 paid holidays and 1 floating holiday and Friday after Thanksgiving is a paid holiday again and the university is closed or "on a break" between Christmas and New Year's for 1 week! Plenty of paid time off!
cons:
No professional advancement
Their HR team sucks BIG TIME!
Horrible maternity leave policy
Very inconsistent application of university policies, not much respect or care for employees
Too many incompetent people getting away with unacceptable behavior and still keeping their jobs! 
Not a thriving environment to improve even though it is a "university" 
Too many senior level people with poor management or soft skills
Very clunky workflow, poor work structure, waste of a lot of tuition money (especially on landscaping!)

review_title: Great for an education, terrible culture as an employee
pros: When you work at Northeastern you have the opportunity to get a free education, which truly is worth it. The faculty is comprised of some of the most incredible individuals from which I have had the pleasure to receive instruction.  I also found that I had good work/life balance being that I was not expected to stay over time and was very rarely contacted outside of the office for work matters.
cons: The culture is quite nasty and people are generally unfriendly. I worked under some of the all time worst superiors I have ever had in my professional life. It wasn't until I was near the end of my time at Northeastern that I finally transitioned to support a truly remarkable leader at the University.

pros:
Pharmacy School
- smart colleagues who are working in community health centers; work is inspiring 
- research colleagues state they are available & want to collaborate; only 1 is a pharmacist
cons:
- work culture can be toxic
- mission & values are not followed 
- upper administration in flux since at least 2008
- surprisingly many faculty do not display a primary commitment/ passion for launching careers for the next generation; few national leaders originate here 
- legitimate claims of workplace bullying (Bill in MA senate) were documented but no action nor resolution resulted

pros: The benefits are really good compared to other places of work.  I get to go to school for free and my boss always lets me take off a day if I really need it.  I am not sure if this is how it is for others. I also like working with students and people around the university.
cons: I feel continually overworked.  I am definitely underpaid.  I often feel as if the senior management cares very little about the workabies in the organization.  there is a clear line between the upper and lower management here.  there is a clear wall between academics and administrators and nobody is willing to try and change this.  The students are the ones who are ultimately affected by the Northeastern "shuffle"

review_title: They keep paying, I keep showing up!
pros: There are a lot of really great people working at Northeastern, and a number of departments are loaded with young professionals that are bringing in new perspectives and innovative approaches to everyday tasks and frequent concerns.
cons: Human Resources does a fairly poor job with nearly everything. Salary negotiations are fairly torturous, the review process tends to diminish individual achievements and therefore a chance for a bonus, and salaries fall at the low ends of the grades. Also, as an internal staff member, you are not allowed to apply for an internal job for at least a year even if you're qualified and the next job in your career path opens up... that is such a ridiculous, archaic policy.

review_title: Postdoc ratings must be taken with a grain of salt
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Location is great.  Located on the MBTA commuter rail, Orange Line, and Green LIne, Northeastern is accessible from a variety of locations.  There is also a large amount of parking available for those that drive.
cons: From a research perspective, the university is lacking in funding and a commitment to support life sciences research.  Simple core facilities such as autoclaves are always broken down and take weeks to repair.  Laboratory space is inadequate, and funds to remodel space for successful investigators do not materialize.  The support staff often does not take their job to support researchers seriously and seems to have serious issues with authority in addition to concerning lack of competency on several fronts (grants management, budgeting, safety and health).

review_title: Amazing Faculty, Difficult Administration, Turn-Around Terror.
pros: The faculty! Bright, engaging, grounded, approachable, impressive, real-world, friendly, professional and truly committed to empowering their students and advancing their specializations. They inspire me everyday.
cons:
Turn-around terror. Incompetent Sarah-Palin-style management have the best running for the door in certain groups. Arrogant senior leadership at the highest levels. Upwards of 45% of some professional units have fled during the last 12 months. This does not include the lightening lay-offs inspired by the new administration. 

More political than the statehouse. Transparency and open feedback are firmly discouraged. The mascot could be a white elephant. This is a shame - Northeastern is an amazing institution and has been a wonderful employer for me for many years. (I remain because I still want to send my teenagers to the university - a terrific benefit!) Great divisions and amazing people still exist, just make sure you do your homework.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Malden, MA
pros: Overall, Northeastern University is a well-rounded school that offers a wonderful college experience and a high-quality education. The campus is beautiful and offers a quiet respite from the larger city of Boston. Northeastern exposes you to city life while still allowing you to feel a sense of community in its enclosed campus. The faculty is helpful, and it is fairly easy to get in touch with the right staff members to assist you with your needs. The co-op program puts you ahead of the game when it comes to job connections, industry knowledge, and professional experience. Most Northeastern students who partake in the co-op program graduate with two or three entry-level jobs on their resume.
cons: The downsides at Northeastern are minimal. Parking can be difficult because the school is in the middle of Boston.

review_title: Amazed that these reviews have no balance. Universal glowing reviews can't be possible. There is room for growth.
pros: There are many colleges within the University and some treat people well and have strong infrastructure and leadership.
cons:
There is not a uniform distribution of any pro or con. It appears this employer or the app has whitewashed the reviews. The overall conclusion of this bring a great place to work cannot possibly be true when averaged across the colleges. If this service is offered, I suggest some quality control. 

I experienced the worst workplace bullying in 35 plus years of employment; further there was no one to go to for help. It was a dark time. 

It should be mentioned that all colleges within the University are NOT represented by the reviews; although they should.

review_title: Fantastic job but artificially limited hours
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros:
For clarity since there are many positions available to outsiders and students at NU: I worked as a graduate research associate for the Center of Democratic Studies, I had a fantastic time working there. 
Flexible hours
Decent pay for a student (couldn't pay rent in Boston on it, but you could afford to eat and have an existence on it)
Satisfying and interesting work, for a graduate student it's a great opportunity getting to work within the field you're studying with a highly experienced professor.
cons: During the school year you have a cap on your hours at 20 and can get in trouble for exceeding that too often.

review_title: quickly growing school is no longer a very fun place to work
pros: Campus location and neighborhood are fairly nice. I have meet great people that work for or with the university at almost all levels, and many of these people have been around the school for quite a while in various capacities. (these people are more often than not leaving the school rapidly) Meager financial compensation across the board (good benefits - bad money)
cons: Since the new senior leadership have been running the show at the school senior staff all across the university is turning over at an incredible rate. In the past 8-10 years what was an excellent place of learning with a blue-collar attitude is now a high-strung work environment with an even tighter budget and a terrible faux nobility attitude.

pros: The school has a good reputation in Electrical Engineering. The faculty is highly qualified. Some top tier schools may have more classes focused on your area of concentration, however you can most likely fill the requirements for a graduate degree with classes that are interesting to you. Plenty of connections with industry due to the centers associated with the university and the location. Many of the students have TAs, though some have RAs. If you would like to get a decent job after your graduation, my advice would be to make as many connections as early on possible. (Industry internships, etc.)
cons: The degree alone will not be your pass into top companies (though the converse is true only for a few schools.)

pros: The overall community and diverse feeling is like no other. There is a great energy and momentum at the University and people are very welcoming and friendly. The location is convenient and most of the benefits are what you would expect out of a Higher Education institution.
cons: There is a hierarchy structure that is sometimes difficult to navigate depending on the office/department. As a result it is sometimes hard to find the right person to talk to in order to get clear answers or you can find you'll get no response at all. Additionally, the most striking flaw in the benefits is that the commuter benefits (MBTA and commuter rail passes) are not subsidized, only pre-taxed amounts. For being an institution that is in the heart of Boston, this seems like an area that should be revisited.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Boston, MA
pros: Generous time off (paid holidays - including almost 2 weeks for Christmas, plentiful sick days, almost 5 weeks vacation time); work on a beautiful campus in Boston; easily commutable via MBTA; improving professional development opportunities depending on where you work on campus
cons: Unrealistic expectations for job responsibilities (advise overload of students, teaching/grading 1-2 sections of co-op courses, job development plus support existing employers; zero work/life balance; complete lack of leadership and vision from the top, disconnect between university leadership and college directors;

pros: The benefits at Northeastern are fantastic and the pay is higher than at most universities in Boston. Most of the people are great and the commute is easy, right on the orange line or green line.  I'm sure working in for the schools and colleges is a different story but the closer you get to the president's office, the more difficult and hellish your life will become.  be wary of the office you choose to work in. Ask good questions regarding why positions are open in the office you might be taking a position in. Are people happy? How quickly do positions turn over.
cons: Trust your employees to do the work you hired them for. Give them the benefit of their experience.

pros: Some of the people are dedicated and wonderful people
cons:
Where to start...it is a good old boys club. The administration needs to wake up and realize why so many women are leaving in droves. Few advancement opportunities are reserved for less educated and less qualified men.

Most systems and programs are lacking. Funding reserved for aesthetics rather than infrastructure or substance. 

Lacking infrastructure and support. Top heavy. No clear strategic plan to address the problems. 

An incredibly frustrating place to work!

review_title: Lab Coordinator / Research Tech position in psych lab
pros: I'm surrounded by fantastic academic scientists that use a variety of methods to pursue large-scale questions in affective science - a highly contentious field. Through the years in the lab, I have acquired an array of skills; some technical and experimentally based, and others concerning large lab logistics, head to toe. I've acquired invaluable insight into how science is conducted in an academic setting and have great respect for the process.
cons: There is very little chance for application within the lab, since the focus of much research initiative is to ask questions and gather answers. Somewhat of a hamster-wheel scenario - thought not entirely unrewarding.

pros: The benefits are generous and hard to beat and eligible staff should really take better advantage of some of these perks.
cons: There is little opportunity for young talent to flourish and have ideas heard in a meaningful way. Central HRM does a decent job with on-boarding; however, managers/academics with little leadership skills or training mean best intentions don't materialize. I don't know how turnover here compares to other universities but there should be little surprise with staff discontent. Benefits keep many eager and talented people around way longer than it should. A shame really.

pros: A lot of very smart, and very motivated people. Pay is good, it's adjusted for the cost of living. Very easy to get to from almost anywhere in the state. Great benefits including health care, tuition reimbursement and insurance benefits. Great divisional management who are dedicated and treat employees with resepect.
cons: Almost no opportunity for upward advancement. Even as someone who has worked here for 4 years, it's almost impossible to get an interview internally for another department. Parking is limited and expensive it's almost always easier to take public transit.  All about the bottom line, upper management often could care less about students.

pros: Northeastern is kind of like a start-up company - there is a lot of opportunity for growth as a student, in administration, and academically. The location is prime, right in the center of Boston.
cons: The start-up like environment can be frustrating, because the administration doesn't always know how to handle research. I feel like we repeat things that have been already figured out at other Universities (not research, but methods of conducting research, professorship, etc.) Also, there has been some issues with getting along with other institutions, like MIT, MGH, NIH - they don't seem to care much about the "Northeastern" name. It's not a bad name, it just doesn't get you any extra mileage.

review_title: Wonderful employer; great colleagues, terrific benefits
job_title: Executive Assistant to Dean in Boston, MA
pros: Smart people doing interesting research and teaching.  Growing number of graduate programs across disciplines. Motivated students, faculty and staff.  Generous benefits, including am amazing retirement plan, with an employer 10% contribution if employee contributes 5% of eligible salary. Summer flex time, tuition benefits, ample paid leave time.
cons: Never personally experienced any downside; very much enjoyed my five years there. Observed the usual turf wars for budgets, faculty positions, staff. (Saw this with a previous employer as well; it's not exclusive to academia!)

review_title: Good school and faculty; admins need a change in perspective.
pros: Supportive departmental faculty and colleagues. Good healthcare benefits. Interesting students, very motivated. Coop program is a great distinction.
cons:
Unsupportive and sometimes downright mean-spirited administrators. Ineffective bureaucracy at the level of Deans, Provost, and support offices. Lots of turnover at these levels exacerbates the problem, and lends a persistent toxicity to the place.

Administrative bloat a major concern at NU. The decision-makers on campus are very often out of touch with the needs and the goals of faculty. Campus amenities, rankings, and the bottom line claim their attention instead.

pros: Benefits are great and pay is pretty good.  Great job location and great credit union with low rates.  Benefits are the key
cons: I can only speak to the hvac dept:  So much politics!!!  If you are not a member of the gang, you are in for a miserable experience.  It will make you immedietely find another job, regardless of pay and benefits just so you can keep your sanity.

review_title: Great opportunity to make a difference for your peers.
pros: I work as a peer tutor for an intro level course in my major. It's incredibly rewarding to help fellow students through their struggles with the material, and when someone leaves your office hours with more understanding than they came in with, it's a great feeling. The course is well organized and well run, and I feel that the prof's that coordinate it are easily approachable and great to work with.
cons: Grading workloads can be excessive, and the rubrics we're given are somewhat vague. Salary could be higher on an hourly basis.

pros: It would seem likely that a University with a focus on graduating students to join the workforce would treat potential employees more professionally.
cons: I had been interviewing with Northeastern for over a year and got to the top tier decision makers. I had lunch with the extended team and had met over 20 people that I was expecting to work with. I spent more time interviewing and writing thank you notes than I ever had in my 20 years of interviewing. I took my candidacy very seriously. I never heard back from them. End of story.

pros: Decent pay, great campus, T accessible.
cons: Shark-like environment. You use one hand to work and the other covering your butt. They’re reactive. They’re trying to figure out how to copy the competition instead of thinking for themselves. They’re very jealous of institutions like General Assembly where people can learn skills without the enormous debt. Campus higher-ups don’t take sexual assault seriousness until the news covers one story and uncovers multiple cases. Has a cool-kid vibe. You’re either with the cool kids are you’re trash. No processes in place. Everyone’s a yes person.

review_title: Seeking a balance between education and business models
pros: Tuition remission is a big benefit as long as your program of choice is not online. The work environment is very collegial within departments and people are passionate about what they do. Able to check your job at the door- outside of 9-5 work expectations are infrequent. Opportunities for growth are present as long as you are willing to move to other departments.
cons: Pay/time off is a little low compared to other universities in the Boston area. The environment is very decentralized- not a great deal of communication between departments. Lastly, because the university is trying to be more competitive they are shifting to a business model that resembles "for-profit" institutions i.e. high recruitment demands

pros: Convenient to public transportation on both the subway and bus. Good benefits and salary.
cons: My cons are directly related to the department I used to work in and not the institution itself. My position in the department was terminated without advance notice and I was not offered a transfer to another position on campus. Other colleges and universities in the Boston area attempt to reassign soon to be displaced staff. I believe the senior manager in my department did not follow human resource recommendations or protocol in my case.

review_title: Underpaid but very flexible, self-directed work
pros:
Flexible hours and excellent location
Self-directed work schedule and creative direction
Publication potential and conference travel
Academic environment encourages learning and improvement
IT support is excellent
Close proximity to Computer Science department for talks and colloquia
cons:
Very underpaid relative to my peers in my field (software engineering)
Benefits package very underwhelming
No time off in the first year, must accrue over time
No retirement matching until after a full year
Very small project team with intermittent drive-by supervision

review_title: It’s what you make of it
pros: NU is a very large organization. The company culture depends on the department you work in. The benefits are extremely competitive in terms of free tution for full-time employees as well as their children. NU contributes 10% to your 403(b) as long as you contribute 5%. The medical, dental, and vision coverage is affordable. You also get most (if not all) holidays off including the time between Christmas and New Years. Those benefits make up for their low salaries.
cons: The organization is layered with management. In a 40 person department, there were 14 managers which is a 3:1 employee to manager ratio.

job_title: Cooperative Education Faculty in Boston, MA
pros: Innovative and constantly looking towards the future - the bigger picture is always in mind. Cutting edge research from faculty, new concepts to evolve with careers and industry, integration of technology. Love working here.
cons: Lots to do to keep up with shifting times and not enough hours in the day. Many new injustices are demanding of time but in the end I am grateful to learn and participate in these opportunities.

review_title: Great people, great university, great place to work.
pros: I work in a research group with great people.  I have as much freedom and as much support as I like.  The salary is competitive and I was able to get additional funding for moving abroad to do research.  I have not spent much time in Boston, but that is also a clear plus.
cons: I cannot really think of any cons.  I work with great people, I have a lot of freedom, I have support, and the pay is competitive; what can I say?  There is a bit of bureaucracy, but not any more than the same job at other places.

review_title: Friendly, motivated, inspiring environment; some crazy hours involved
pros: Great, personable, community-based environment with excellent benefits. Everyone really believes in the place and you can have some incredible colleagues who are insanely talented and become lifelong friends. Depending on where you are, you can handle a variety of really cool projects, and advancement is possible, as upper level folks do acknowledge and appreciate your efforts.
cons: Depending on your department, you can work crazy hours to meet just-sprung deadlines that directly conflict with your existing workload. Employees are very devoted and maintain good spirits, but it can be exhausting and sometimes demoralizing. Pay is decent, but not great unless you're on a high supervisory level.

pros: I've been at Northeastern for almost 15 years and have been promoted 5 times.  There are lots of great opportunities if you work for them.  The university has been on the move up for some time,  I love the mission of the institution and the energy of being on a college campus.  Pay is good.  Benefits are very good.
cons: The pace is very fast.  You need to know that going in and find a way to balance work and home life.  It can be very political in some departments.

job_title: Assistant Academic Specialist in Boston, MA
pros:
+ As others have said, location is good, easily accessible by public transportation. 
+ Yes, there are career opportunities, but when there's that much turnover, you have to be suspicious of WHY
cons:
-pervasive culture of fear and corporate greed that I believe is keeping many people from writing realistic reviews on here
-I feared and still fear retribution for speaking out against them 
-my ethics were pushed to the limits until they reached the breaking point

pros: Collegues are wonderful if you can get to know them. Extremely capable and creative colleagues. Cutting edge programming. Opportunity to be in the trenches and learn. Ambitious goals.
cons: Toxic work environment.  Attrition rate over the top. No continuity. No faith in leadership to make changes to retain talent until too late.

review_title: There is a lot of room for growth here and a real sense of community.
pros: The benefits are very good and the free tuition great! There are a lot of managers who love to see their employees grow as people and in their careers.
cons: Working with students can sometimes be a thankless job and you must be very self-motivated and maintain a good attitude. They can and will push your patience to the limit.

pros: The campus is gorgeous and there are some wonderful people to work with across all divisions.  The institution is innovative which is a cool experience to be a part of as well.
cons: The salaries are low compared to the area.  Depending on your office, there are some really bad politics that weigh on you.  If you cannot play the game it is not the place to be, especially since schmoozers get ahead here.  The spend a lot as well so it seems frivolous, especially if you yourself went to college here.

review_title: This position is a great entry level position.
pros: It is a great job for me to have straight out of college.  Has great benefits, community of staff, and my own office.  I also feel confident (during these uncertain times) that they are trustworthy and will provide me with job security.
cons: It is a really big organization and can sometimes feel very disconnected.  I also think they waste a lot of money.

pros: Tuition waiver, access to facilities, network building, constantly innovating their position in higher education.
cons: Seeing higher educations downfalls in person - gross over spending, misappropriation of funds, bloated salaries on tenured faculty.  Impossible to go around personality conflicts - power players typically don't move (and if they still remain in power).

job_title: Mail Services Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Friendly environment and allowed me to work while taking classes at Northeastern University. They make sure you are able to handle any task while your are working.
cons: Since I was a student I could only work 20 hours a week . While working a proctor I did not like that you had to come in an hour earlier before your shift just so that you can pick the resident building you would  like to work at.

pros: I worked in the Co-op department for 8 months as a student coordinator. Pros were that everyone was welcoming and willing to help with day-to-day experiences and future career development. I worked with everyone form fellow graduate students to the associate dean of the college. It definitely gave me great insight into the world of higher education.
cons: The one big con I noticed was that internship opportunities rarely, if ever, translated into full time positions. Even when they needed another full time employee they stuck with the part-time intern. I'm not sure if it is budget constraints, bureaucracy, or a combination of both.

review_title: Typical Higher Ed - Politics, Egos, entitlement
pros: Nice technology, free tuition with lots of degree choices.  That;'s really the only decent reason to work there, is to get a degree of some kind. lots of vacation days
cons: Some individuals have been there longer than most of the buildings.  Many of the buildings flood on a regular basis, and guess where the data centers are...That's right, the basements, because they wouldn't think of insulting the faculty by putting them in a moldy basement somewhere

review_title: The job did a lot for me too pass on to my children.
pros: The workshop's that we was giving was the best every. Showing the Parent's and the students how important it was to stay and school.
cons: workshop that we had to attend. The early morning work homework that we had to do. The field trip overnight camping trip with the students. College tour's was great showed me thing that I could share with my daughters.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: The campus is nice, it feels like a real campus rather than just part of the city (i.e. universities like BU). There are many on-going collaborations with schools and hospitals in the area.
cons: Not a collaborative environment in the sense of instrument use or getting help from others. If you're joining a research lab without all the instruments you will need for your research, I would recommend looking into it further.

review_title: Great experience showcasing my skills which ultimately ended up with a job
pros: I had the opportunity to work under Professor Nik Bear Brown of AI Skunkworks as part of Northeastern University. It was a great experience and he gave me full freedom to express my thoughts on the COVID-19 situation. I got a job within one month of joining and had to quit.
cons: No cons. Professor Nik Brown is the best professor who shows real compassion to students especially international students. Other professor ought to learn a thing or two from this man!! There is no use of gaining so much knowledge unless you help out students.

review_title: Great faculty, top notch research, cutting edge facilities.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: As a graduate research assistant, I have been able to work on cutting edge research here at the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. The Engineering faculty at Northeastern receives the second highest number of funded projects in the New England area after MIT. Great facilities especially if you are into MEMS/ Semiconductor hardware. the cleanroom facilities are top notch.
cons: The downsides are simply the same as in any graduate school research work. Sometimes you are stuck with a problem whose solution you don't even know exists. But to work through this barriers and uncertainties make research even more fun.

review_title: Great environment, cool co-workers, productive and helpful staff
pros: The Staff is willing and able to work with and direct new staff in their new roles.  Supervisors are visible and engaged in the needs of staff and customers alike.  There is a fair balance between time sensitive rush jobs and general duties.
cons: With the ever-growing college there are past oversights that catch up with them; requiring data gathering of installed equipment (Serial numbers, model numbers, MAC addresses etc.).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Ability to choose times to work. Location is not too bad, not too good either (shootings or robberies a few times per year in surrounding neighborhoods). Campus feels relatively safe though.
cons: Salary is too low for Boston, health insurance is bad, no dental or vision insurance, no paid sick days, no regulated holidays, no parental leave. The employer has all power of you and you have almost no voice. No workers union to help with bargaining.

review_title: Great part-time job at the College of Arts, Media & Design (CAMD)!
pros: Really such an amazing job! My boss at the time - the Communications and Digital Strategy Manager - was fantastic and very supportive. She knew I loved art and design so gave me a lot of creative projects to work on. I was also able to gain more experience using WordPress to publish website content, and even had a chance to write articles for CAMD's site.
cons: I honestly can't think of any downsides about working there - only that I couldn't work there more hours because of my class schedule at the time!

review_title: Don't waste your summer working for them as a student, get a real internship
pros: I get to do software development for a certain department(not CS focused) because I think what they are doing is fun and unique.
cons:
I think I did a good job and I keep working on the project for a year. After I graduate, they refuse to give me a raise and will only hire me as a part-time worker. I could have worked as an intern for a big company but I passed that opportunity up because I like what they are doing.

This is the worst decision I ever made in my life.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Top quality facilities. Interesting and smart people. School is growing in a way that places them competitively among top tier Universities in Boston (Harvard, MIT). The research is improving as more faculty are hired and the university utilizes its location to enhance collaborative work.
cons: Rapid growth to become a larger research university means the infrastructure is lagging a bit behind. There seems to be checks put in place that are making it difficult for the growth period to happen smoothly. Hard to tell how it will turn out as the consequences/benefits may not be evident for another 3-5 years.

review_title: Most toxic culture I’ve ever experienced
pros: Good list of benefits if you’re a full time employee with a family. Great 401k but you have to work there for a few years before you can get the benefit, so it’s almost not worth it.
cons: The closer you work to the president, the more toxic the culture is. Senior leadership doesn’t treat anyone below them like people, instead refer to them as “resources.” Most people are so caught up in proving themselves to the president and making him happy that they derail projects, forget any moral code, and will fire anyone that raises any honest and valid concern. They say they want to compete with the top tech companies talent-wise but they won’t pay accordingly. Senior leadership is making $500k but they won’t pay developers and designers what they’re worth in the market and actually take away projects so they can justify a lower salary. I have seen people do and say things here that make my stomach churn. Every project is treated like an emergency and no one knows how to properly manage deadlines, so the people who actually have to do the work are forced under such immense pressure and are beyond stressed most of the time. Turnover is HIGH - most people in this department have been here less than a year and most will not stay longer than that. It’s really a shame because this has the potential to be an incredible place to work and a place where you can meaningfully contribute to the world, but people’s egos have destroyed any hope of that.

pros: In-processing is welcoming, helpful, and professional. Clear policies and visible leadership. Good communication.
cons:
Intense pressure for individual (even low-level) employees to improve Northeastern's image. The university is constantly trying to boost its brand and reputation. 
In performance reviews, managers are instructed to set their standards so high that "exceptional" should be the norm. On a 5-tier ranking system, managers are actively discouraged from giving any higher than 3.

review_title: A secure job, but am undervalued for my education and experience.
pros: The benefits are very good and are generally what attract people towards working in higher education. Depending on where in the university you work, there may be other benefits.
cons: There is a lack of professional growth opportunities, and the university doesn't really invest in its employees. We are undervalued for our education and experiences, which is interesting considering the university prides itself in producing employable students with their degrees. NEU would be very unhappy if their students ended up in jobs with salaries similar to what it offers its employees.

job_title: Work Study Student in Boston, MA
pros: Working as a work study at Northeastern University is a great opportunity as a student. You can almost pick your hours to work around your class and life schedule, the work is generally fairly relaxed, and you can often even use your work study funding to get paid while doing research with a professor; gaining valuable experience while getting paid too.
cons: You need to acquire work study funding, which is need based by FAFSA, to get many jobs on campus and especially if you want to get paid while doing research.

pros: Being a note taker was simple for me, since I take very detailed notes in class already. I just had to scan them and organize the scans into PDFs each day. You're compensated for class time and scan time. Scanners are easy to access on campus too.
cons: The timesheet system is clunky to use; it's all drop-down menus, so it's slow to select start and end times to report your hours, and the webpage refreshes after almost any action you do. There are not many hours to work per week (both a pro and con).

job_title: Senior Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: It's in Boston, which means that great people get selected into this place (James Dana, William Dickens, John Kwoka).
cons: The economics department has very limited funding, which means that PhD's like myself had very little job safety. Although promised 4 years of full coverage, we were told at the end of the third year that there would be no benefits for the fourth. Finally, they found the money, but the whole process caused us a great deal of stress. Students with Masters degrees are only offered 4 years of funding whereas post-Bachelor students only 5 years.

pros: It helps you build your communication skills. Really helpful for those whose first language is not English.
cons: Sometimes ppl don't actually care about how hard you have been working on just one subject. They can easily miss the point.

pros: The management is generally pretty flexible.  If you need to come in late, leave early, work from home, etc. they try to accommodate.  If you do your job and get your work done, you will be left alone.
cons: The management is chaotic.  Hard to accomplish anything that touches more than a handful of people.  Lots of things are proposed, and never followed up on.

review_title: Great Benefits But No Room to Grow
pros: Great benefits (health, eye, sick time, maternity leave...)
cons:
Stagnant, no room to move up.
The hiring process and promotion process is extremely slow.
The management is mediocre.  
The workload can go from 0-100%, it's not consistent

review_title: Takes Very Good Care of Their Employees
pros: Good Pay, Good People, Lots of events that give away free stuff, Occasionally get free meals, Located in a central part of Boston. Beautiful location.
cons: There is a a pretty big problem with the organization of the college. Management often changes around. Many of the upper level managers have inflated egos and don't understand what it's like to be a lower level worker.

pros: It is growing university with good opportunities. Its location is excellent, has very nice facilities and the salary was satisfying.
cons: You don't really get a campus feeling. And it still has some way to go before it gets the reputation it deserves. But it seems like it is on the right track.

pros: Being a TA for some of the higher level classes and being able to talk to students one-on-one is a really good feeling. It's easy to sympathize with struggles you've already gone through, and being able to help someone through a problem that really hurt back when you took a class is deeply gratifying. Flexible hours, great professors.
cons: Office hour scheduling can be difficult, seeing as supervising professors need to book rooms before they know their TA schedules.

pros: Excellent professor, great group of researchers, Research project of great interest and significant learning.
cons: None, everything is wonderful, as long as student is able to manage it well. If rigorous research and continuous learning is too hectic, Research Assistantship can be a big task.

job_title: Global Student Ambassador in Boston, MA
pros:
• Engaged incoming students throughout orientation process by planning and leading activities,
assembling reading materials, providing peer mentoring and advising and leading campus tours
• Planned and led ongoing campus events and student service program to engage students in school and
surrounding community
cons: Language and diversified culture are the disadvantages. Because we are working in the global environment where has so many students coming from many countries all over the world.  English is as a second language of many international students; therefore, miscommunication is the weakness that we can't deny.

review_title: As a customer service rep (CSR), its a great place to make connections.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: I had a great sales leader who would have been a great mentor had I wanted to pursue the sales track.
cons: The hierarchy did not lend much concern to the advancement of the entry-level folks. They didn't seem to concerned with cultivating talent.

review_title: There are a lot of people at Northeastern who simply do not  care when you have a problem or need help.
pros: Good co-op programs for undergrads. Beautiful campus. Study oversees programs. International and gender diversity. Good health insurance. New buildings. Good scientific facilities. Situated in Boston Downtown which is great.
cons: It seems that people are just way too stressed at Northeastern so it is difficult to enjoy the overall atmosphere.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Boston is a beautiful city and NEU is in a great location (very close to downtown) making it easy to access with public transportation.
cons:
It is really costly to live and winters are so cold and long. NEU has recently become very popular for undergrad education due to its coop program which resulted in too many students for a small area.
Your happiness from graduate research assistantship is mostly dependent on your adviser and it is not a rare event to come across with a bad one.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
cons: Enlarged pathway students group ruined the students future and leave them no opportunities in the job market but to enter the graduate school or go back to their own countries

job_title: Clinical Associate Professor in Boston, MA
pros: A university on the rise. It has recently been ranked as one of the top fifty universities in the country.
cons: The older faculty are still adjusting to contemporary teaching methods and to the demands of today's students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: I am Graduate Research assistant at Dr. Torchilin's lab at Northeastern University. I work with renal cancer cells. It has been a great learning experience. I have gained experience in various laboratory techniques. I carry out cell culture experiments and also in-vivo testings.
cons: It is a very competitive laboratory with a number of Phd students and I feel privileged to be a part of this team. There is a lot of hardwork involved but at the same time the work environment is very motivating.

pros: this is a very good opportunity to work on campus. you can meet a lot of students from different major, had a lot of fun
cons: I don't see any cons. maybe it did take some of your study time, but all is good. you tutee student love to sit down with you about their questions

review_title: Lucky to have a Good Work Team, Not so good Campus Environment
pros: Excellent Benefits & Access to University Resources, FT Employees have Access to earning Degrees at significantly discounted price, Good Work Life Balance depending on department
cons: Low Pay compared to other Universities in the Area, Bureaucratic Environment, Slow to Change, Not Racially Diverse Student Population or Employee Population, Not much room for upward growth for lower level positions

review_title: Wonderful place for grad school to do solid work without super high stress
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: I really enjoy it here, very nice culture, no tight schedules to follow, reasonable deadlines, select your own advisor type deal
cons: No sense of community or real connection made for me as a graduate student.  It's easy to lock yourself away from everyone.

job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Boston, MA
pros: Professors that often times could have been across the puddle at MIT but got better start up lab money from Northeastern do fantastic research.
cons: There is a lot of run-around with paperwork i.e faculty that know there is a process but each one thinks it should be done a different way with different people.

pros:
There are some great people scattered across D'Amore-McKim and the experience was overall valuable. 

NEU is a great employer and offers great benefits! The pros of this employer are primarily thanks to NEU as a whole, and the cons of this review are not intended reflect poorly on NEU as an institution. The high ratings for career opportunities and compensation/benefits are for NEU, not D'Amore-McKim.
cons: Serious lack of professionalism among those in long-term D'Amore-McKim leadership positions, among other significant cultural issues.

pros: Strategy-wise the university is very forward-thinking and invests in growing fields including data science, data visualization and digital humanities, and in general highly encourages interdisciplinary research and provides funding for research projects across departments.
cons: As at all universities, some professors are self-absorbed and very difficult to work with. It's important to make a careful choice of advisor.

review_title: Designed algorithms while working under professor
job_title: Computer Science Professor's Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Learned interesting things while working with a professor at northeastern, I developed algorithms to solve problems funded by NSF grants.
cons: Because of limited funding, my assistanceship was not renewed, so my time was limited at the university.  I felt this limited our ability to complete research

review_title: Confusing but good place to work
pros: Vacation, location, people, health and retirement benefits (after two years) are all excellent.
cons: It's a private university but you could definitely make much more money for the same job at a "private sector" company.

review_title: Growing university but repressive corporate culture
pros: Countless opportunities to develop as a teaching professional. Talented and innovative colleagues on a dynamic urban campus. Motivated students and constantly improving facilities.
cons: Poor academic management. Corporate approach to education. Insufficient support from HR.  Questionable university financial investments in fossil fuels and alleged use of off-shore shell companies to avoid taxes.

pros: Location is great. Transportation, restaurants, hospitals... There are lots of chances can have a job. Many companies and lots of job fair are here. You can go to MIT or Harvard for the job fair easily.
cons: University isn't well known yet. There are Harvard, MIT, BU and BC near here. High life expenses is a problem.

review_title: So far so good at Northeastern!
pros: Great staff, odd students that keep you laughing and having fun. The desks are super big and the chairs are the softest, cushiest things you've ever sat in!
cons: The students are odd. :) They keep things interesting! It's also a hike from where ever you park. Depends on which building you work in.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
Large network, access to resources if you are proactive
Focus on developing research
Provide emphasis and support for transformative research
cons:
Experience depends greatly on who your research adviser is
Some care about helping their students graduate
Other only care about number of publications, not quality
Others care about taking IP for themselves. Be Careful!

pros: Great collaborative atmosphere that recieves strong administrative support, open to new ideas outside the traditional high education mold, competitive salary.
cons: Chances of advancing career within university not strong. Internal candidates do not have advantage nor given priority over outside candidates when open positions arise.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Boston, MA
pros: The benefits are pretty decent, the environment is good, friendly people, every chance to meet and interact with students is an extra benefit.
cons: The salary is low, the opportunities for career advancement are very limited and the bureaucracy even for the simplest issues is enormous.

review_title: I have had a great experience at Northeastern being able to work in many situations with great people.
pros: There is a world of opportunities at Northeastern. Great benefits package, including tuition reimbursement.
cons: I am not challenged enough in my current position. I feel that I am capable of many great things, however I don't feel that my opinion is valued as much as it should be.

review_title: Coming from a student Employee at ITS
job_title: Service Desk Technician/Supervisor in Boston, MA
pros: I worked at the ITS Help Desk and it was an enjoyable experience. People were dynamic and there was always something to do and new problems to solve. The schedule was also very flexible.
cons: As a student it is difficult to affect real change in the workplace and communication between management needs to be improved

pros: Flexibility is great. The supervisors are passionate about their vocation and are also willing to help you learn and overcome challenges in your own work. Able to work from home.
cons: The atmosphere can be competitive at times, however, this drives and motivates people. It is a research university after all.

pros: Large research university with an outstanding programming languages research department.
cons: While the work as an undergraduate tutor is interesting, and helps you learn the material better, the grading assignments come irregularly in large clumps. You'll have no work one week, and then an unusually large amount of work the next.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Great professors, great campus, great people
cons: Very boring and uncomfortable Lab spaces, Out dated courses available to take at each semester (for graduate students)

job_title: Call Center Employee in Boston, MA
pros: Very supportive work environment, energetic supervisor. They set goals for us and were flexible with scheduling and taking days off. There were a lot of student employees in the alumni call center.
cons: The job itself was at the call center which wasn't the most exciting. It was also located in the basement of a building which was a bit depressing (no windows).  I imagine other work areas are different though!

review_title: Masters Level Computer Science Teaching Assistant
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Supervisors are easy to communicate with
- Supports remote instruction
- Access to helpful learning material.
cons: Due to transitioning to an online contingency (COVID-19 ), there were significant changes to the course structure(s) from higher-up that caused a lot of issues in grading expectations and communication with the students. The need for change was not the university's fault and the instructors were accommodating, so maintained at 4 stars.

pros: Great HR personnel and support.
cons: It is a general rule that if you have difficulty with a manager the school is hesitant to consider looking into the problem.

job_title: Media Services Technician in Boston, MA
pros: Best bosses, great work environment, great benefits with respect to flexibility and coverage. Great learning experience.
cons: No cons. Could not find any con as the pay is good, work is interesting, ample hours, management is great and benefits are great.

pros: in a very nice city and the travel is convinient and the pay is good . basically awesome place to work and live
cons: the reputation of the university is not that good. students are not very competitive for job hunting.  but it is glowing fast

pros: Everyone there, including the students is very career oriented which keeps you motivated while you're working. The passion people have is inspiring!
cons:
Lots of run-around/ red tape
Not enough communication between colleges or departments within a college--people are stuck in the "Husky Shuffle," being sent from one building to another because no one understands what goes on outside of their position.

review_title: A year in the PLAIT game research lab of Northeastern University.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Have met a lot of people from the game development industry, got some insider information during the talks and conferences. The students and faculty are very nice people as well.
cons: The requirements and timelines are vague, the Ph.D. committee makes it's decisions in a rather black-box manner, and they may be totally unexpected for the non-faculty Ph.D. students, or staff.

review_title: More like a corporation than a university.
pros: most of colleagues are great people. Students are diverse and exciting to worth with.
cons: Management is absolutely top-down, and there is far too much emphasis on moving up the rankings. The provost is a dictator (largely disliked by the faculty), and upper management tends to disregard or ignore faculty concerns. It has become a toxic work environment. Gender discrimination is very real.

pros: Flexible - Ability to work at your own pace - you can use life experiences with this particular position. Moving through the company is not difficult and is encouraged. If hired full time you and your children can attend free of charge.
cons: Pay scale should be better. More money is pay for those holding a Bachelors or higher level degree but no consideration for those holding an Associate Degree.

pros: Amazing benefits if you are interested in pursuing higher education. The culture is supportive of this which allows for flexibility at work while you are taking classes. Generous time off as well.
cons: Very little room for growth or movement. The performance review process does not include growth and development programs. Other than taking classes towards a degree, this is not a company that promotes internal movement.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros: There are some good professors doing interesting research there.  The area is rich for collaborations
cons: NEU still has a ways to go in becoming a strong research institute.  The senior leadership wants to be stronger in research without investing in the infrastructure.

review_title: Boston is great city, co-op program is excellent, student body too homogeneous, classes lacking
pros:
- Co-op program
- Boston is fun city
- Student activities are great
- Campus is beautiful
- Mostly new buildings
cons:
- Student body too homogeneous
- Professors not so great
- Many professors foreign
- Very high tuition
- Class selection not very diversified

pros:
Location
Sense of Community
Not difficult work
cons:
You don't get paid nearly enough for the hours you put in. 
My department said a TA was approximately 20 hours. However to be an effective TA, you need to put more than 20 hours in a week.
Time Consuming 
Dealing with people who aren't appreciate of the work and hours you put in

review_title: Great school and so much potential
pros: Benefits, vacation and sick time are a huge plus. Great for someone looking to earn a Master's degree while working full time.
cons: While the benefits are a pro, the salary is a con. Raises are barely enough to keep up with inflation and bonuses are really not existent.

job_title: DRC Note Taker in Boston, MA
pros: Easiest job I've ever had. You basically get paid to go to class and take notes. And you are compensated generously for it. I especially like that the DRC rewards returning notetakers by bumping up their hourly salary by $0.50 or so.
cons: You have to go to class every day because someone who isn't able to take their own notes is depending on you.

review_title: Avoid Administrative Roles within Certain Departments
pros:
Lots of opportunity to learn various aspects of all sorts of positions within higher education. 
Excellent benefit package for full time employees (including tuition).
Changes in current management seem to be underway and for the better.
cons:
Administrative roles within Bouve' College of Health Sciences experience high turn over and riddled in poor management and senior level management. 
Administrative employee's  along with the students and faculty of Bouve' are seen as numbers and only hold fiscal relevancy to the college.
Senior Management charades itself as innovative and inclusive while holding true to a rigid autocratic management style giving way to lots of interoffice gossip behind the scenes ridicule/pecking orders that are in no way constructive or positive work environments.
Senior Management remains blissfully unaware of the true day to day operations that hold their department or college together. They offer no training or support to administrative staff from the beginning of hire through the duration of employment as they simply do not know how to, nor want to understand the roles of many other than their own.
No work life balance exists for those acquiring more work along with no foreseeable incentives.
New ideas or innovative suggestions are often scoffed at behind closed doors. 
Constant failures on behalf of management to move any/all positive changes to full resolution either due to lack of ability/competence in their own roles or for fear of ruffling senior management feathers.

review_title: Fast-paced environment where priorities are always changing. Great "job", but not a "career"
pros:
Great benefits including free tuition. 
Good work-life balance; the university is typically on a 830-430 schedule. 
Fast-paced and never dull!
cons:
Lack of organizational structure.
Not strategy focused.
Lack of career progression.
Top heavy.

pros: They have very good location, center of Boston, MA, which brings you more opportunities than you think.
cons: The University is still on it's trajectory for being the Top Level University of the world, Students, Teachers, and Funding have a big space of doing better.

review_title: Becoming greater than America is each and every second!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Great technology, Snell library is a wonder in its own. from free 3-d printing workshops to on-rent projectors the library packs everything any student needs to develop. Great focus on sports. Decent on-campus availability of jobs. Great diversity in the college crowd. Feels like an international campus instead of an American one.
cons: A bit expensive. Not fully developed yet.

pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Northeastern University are: it's good learning environment, helpful management, casual work environment
cons: Some of the downsides of working at Northeastern University are: it can be monotonous, unhelpful management, at times frustrating customer service

pros: Great location in Boston, exciting up and coming academic environment, fantastic co-workers, good benefits (as is the case with most higher ed employers)
cons: Broken senior leadership, administrative turf wars, constant political wrangling, fear, capricious decision-making, poor work life balance, unnecessarily stressful atmosphere that filters down from top to bottom

review_title: Great place to pick up skills and move on.
pros: Great opportunity to hon your skills.
cons: Poor upper management. Salary increases are week. Annual review process is a joke. Tuition remission for online courses is not permitted, Revolving door at times.

review_title: Producing live sports broadcasts and editing videos for the athletic department was an amazing experience.
pros: Good on-the-job training, exciting travel opportunities for top level producers, great team environment with excellent camaraderie
cons: Irregular hours, good deal of night and weekend work, all positive other than the sometimes inconvenient scheduling.

pros: The people you work with at Northeastern are always there to assist and teach you if needed. They treat you like family and make the work place very enjoyable.
cons: Some of the systems and procedures in place are out of date. It takes a very long time for changes to be made due to having to go through the chain of command to receive approval.

review_title: College of Art, Media + Design needs to get it's act together
pros: Great Faculty,  Talented Students,
cons: Old dean was a disgrace, new dean is a micromanager, doesn't consult faculty and has no grasp of technology.

review_title: Great experience with a very understanding group of supervisors.

cons: The compensation could be better, but it is a work-study position so it was not bad.

review_title: Excellent professional environment with productive work--life balance
job_title: Research Associate Professor in Boston, MA

review_title: Fantastic faculty, entrepreneurial spirit, great colleagues

cons: High turnover (or no turnover where there should be), lower salaries than other academic institutions, slow hiring process

pros: Strong support for graduate research students in the area of research development, career services, network building, and personal development

cons: It is a good school but it is close to two of the best school in the world (Harvard and MIT) and sometimes it might compare with those schools.
